GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
§ 70.01  SCOPE OF TRAFFIC CODE.
   (A)   This traffic code shall be known and cited as and hereinafter referred
to as the “Traffic Code of Arcadia” or as “this title” or as the “traffic
code”.
   (B)   The provisions of the traffic code are intended to apply to all
traffic and to all operators not specifically excepted.
   (C)   All provisions relative to the operation, parking or movement of
vehicles or animals, and to the movement of pedestrians, apply upon all the
public ways of the town, except as specifically limited.
   (D)   The provisions of the traffic code shall in no way limit, alter or
otherwise affect the civil or criminal responsibility of any person under the
laws of the state.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:01)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.02  PUBLICLY-OWNED ROADWORKS AND AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES.
   (A)   The provisions of this title applicable to the drivers of vehicles on
a highway, street, alley or other public ways shall apply to the drivers of all
vehicles owned or operated by the United States, the state or any county, city,
town, district or any other political subdivision of the state, subject to such
specific exceptions contained in the traffic code or the laws of the state or
of the United States.
   (B)   Unless specifically made applicable, the provisions of the traffic
code shall not apply to persons, motor vehicles and other equipment while
actually engaged in work on the surface of a highway, street or alley, but
shall apply to such persons and vehicles when traveling to or from work.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:02)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.03  RIDING OR DRIVING ANIMAL.
   Every person riding an animal or driving any animal drawing a vehicle of any
type upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of this traffic code
applicable to the drivers of a motorized vehicle, except those provisions of
this traffic code which, by their nature, can have no application.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:03)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.04  PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   Nothing in the traffic code shall be construed to prevent the owner of real
property used by the public for vehicular travel, by permission of the owner
and not as a matter of right or law, from:
   (A)   Prohibiting such use;
   (B)   Requiring other or different or additional conditions than those
specified in the traffic code; or
   (C)   Otherwise regulating such use as may seem best to such owner.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:04)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.05  STANDING OR PARKING OF VEHICLES.
   The provisions of the traffic code prohibiting the standing or parking of a
vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as
indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to
avoid a conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a
police officer or official traffic-control device.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:05)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.06  NON-CONFLICTING OR NON-DUPLICATING ORDINANCES.
   Pursuant to I.C. 9-4-1-27, local authorities may adopt by ordinance
additional traffic regulations with respect to streets and highways under their
jurisdiction so long as they do not conflict with or duplicate the provisions
of a statute. If any section or provision of the traffic code duplicates or is
in conflict with state statutes, then the state statutes shall prevail and the
Marshal and his or her deputies shall enforce the state statute and not the
provision or section of the traffic code which may duplicate or be in conflict
with the statute. If any term, section or provision of the traffic code in
adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction to be in conflict with or a
duplication of state statute and in violation of I.C. 9-4-1-27, then the
Council shall take corrective action to amend, modify or delete the offending
section or provision and to do all things necessary to bring the offending
section or provision of the traffic code into compliance with state law (I.C.
9-4-1-27). Any section or provision of the traffic code which has been ruled by
a court of competent jurisdiction to be in conflict with or a duplication of
state statute and in violation of I.C. 9-4-1-27 shall not affect the remaining
terms, provisions, conditions, sections and penalties of the traffic code which
shall remain in full force and effect.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:06)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.07  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this traffic code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALLEY. A public thoroughfare which affords only secondary means of vehicular
access to abutting property and not over 20 feet in width.
   AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE. Vehicles of the Fire Department, Police
Vehicles and such ambulances as are operated by or for health and hospital
corporations pursuant to state law. However, ambulances and other vehicles,
which are owned by persons, firms or corporations other than hospitals, and are
used in emergency service, may be designated as EMERGENCY VEHICLES if such
vehicles are authorized to operate as such by the Public Service Commission of
the state.
   BICYCLE. Any foot-propelled vehicle, irrespective of the number of wheels in
contact with the ground.
   BUREAU. The Bureau of Motor Vehicles of the state acting directly or through
its duly authorized officers and agents.
   BUS. Every motor vehicle designed for carrying passengers for hire and used
for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other than a
taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation.
   BUSINESS DISTRICT. The territory contiguous to and including a highway when
50% or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of 500 feet or more is
occupied by buildings in use for business.
   COMMERCIAL VEHICLE. Every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for
the transportation of property.
   COMMISSION. The state’s Highway Commission, acting directly or through its
duly authorized officers and agents.
   COMMISSIONER. The Commissioner of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles of the state.
   CONTROLLED-ACCESS HIGHWAY. Every highway, street or roadway in respect to
which owners or occupants of abutting property or lands and other persons have
no legal right of access, except at such points only and in such manner as may
be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway,
street or roadway.
   CROSSWALK.
      (1)   The part of a roadway at an intersection included within the
connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the
highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of
the traversable roadway; and
      (2)   Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly
indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface.
   CURB LOADING ZONE. A space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use
of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials.
   DEPARTMENT. A Police Department of the state acting directly or through its
duly authorized agents.
   DIRECTOR. The Director of Traffic Safety of the state.
   DRIVER. Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a
vehicle.
   DAY. A period of time consisting of 24 consecutive hours and measured from
12:01 a.m. to 12:01 a.m. of the next succeeding day.
   EXPLOSIVES. Any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly
used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and which contains
any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions,
quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by concussion, by
percussion or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause
such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous
pressures are capable of producing destructible effects on contiguous objects
or of destroying life or limb.
   FARM TRACTOR. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm
implement for drawing plows, moving machines and other implements of husbandry.
   FLAMMABLE LIQUID. Any liquid which has a flash point of 70° F., or less, as
determined by a Tagliabue or equivalent closed-cup test device.
   FREIGHT CURB LOADING ZONE. A space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use
of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight or passengers.
   GROSS WEIGHT. The weight of a vehicle without load, plus the weight of any
load thereon.
   INDIVIDUAL PARKING SPACE. A portion of the paved surface of the street of
sufficient length and depth from the sidewalk, curb or edge of the roadway to
accommodate a vehicle of standard size.
   INTERSECTION.
      (1)   The areas embraced, within the prolongation or connection of the
lateral curb lines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways
of two highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles,
or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at
any other angle may come in conflict; and
      (2)   Where a highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then
every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting
highway shall be regarded as a separate INTERSECTION. In the event such
intersecting highway also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then
every crossing of two roadways of such highway shall be regarded as a separate
INTERSECTION.
   LANED HIGHWAY. A highway the roadway of which is divided into three or more
clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic.
   LOCAL AUTHORITIES. Every county, municipal and other local board or body
having authority to adopt local police regulations under the constitution and
laws of the state.
   MARSHAL. The chief law enforcement officer of the town. Also, the Chief of
the town’s Police Force.
   METAL TIRE. Every tire the surface of which in contact with the highway is
wholly or partly of metal or other hard non-resilient material.
   MOTOR VEHICLE. Every vehicle, except a motorized bicycle, which is self-
propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from
overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails.
   MOTORCYCLE. Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and
designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground,
but excluding a tractor or a therapeutic bicycle.
   MOTORIZED BICYCLE. A bicycle with operable pedals which may be propelled by
human power or by an internal combustion engine or battery powered motor, or by
both, and when powered by an internal combustion engine having a rating of no
more than one and five-tenths brake horsepower and a cylinder capacity not
exceeding 50 cubic centimeters, an automatic transmission and a maximum design
speed of no more than 25 mph on a flat surface.
   OFFICE OF TRAFFIC SAFETY. The Office of Traffic Safety of the state acting
directly or through its duly authorized officers and agents.
   OFFICIAL TIME STANDARD. Standard time or daylight saving time, as may be in
current use in the town.
   OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES. All signs, signals, markings and devices,
not inconsistent with this traffic code, placed or erected for the purpose of
regulating, warning or guiding traffic by authority of a public body or
official having jurisdiction.
   OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNAL. Any device not inconsistent with this
traffic code, whether manually, electronically or mechanically operated, by
which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed.
   OWNER. A person who holds the legal title of a vehicle, in the event a
vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease
thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in
the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the
conditional vendee or lessee, or in the event a mortgagor of a vehicle is
entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor
shall be deemed the OWNER for the purpose of this title.
   PARK. The standing of a vehicle, whether or occupied or not.
   PASSENGER CURB LOADING ZONE. A place adjacent to a curb reserved for the
exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers.
   PEDESTRIAN. Any person afoot.
   PERSONS. Every natural person, firm, co-partnership, association or
corporation.
   PNEUMATIC TIRE. Every tire in which compressed air is designed to support
the load.
   POLE TRAILER. Every vehicle without motor power designed to be drawn by
another vehicle and attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach, or
pole, or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle. Ordinarily
used for transporting long or irregular shaped loads such as poles, pipes or
structural members, capable, generally, of sustaining themselves as beams
between the supporting connections.
   POLICE OFFICER. Every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to
make arrests for violations of traffic regulations.
   PRIVATE BUS. Every motor vehicle designed and constructed for the
accommodation of passengers, which is used for transportation of passengers by
a religious organization, fraternal, charitable, benevolent or youth
association. The term PRIVATE BUS shall include either the chassis or the body
of the vehicle, or shall include both the body and the chassis of any such
vehicle; provided that, any vehicle having the seating capacity of ten persons
or less shall not be deemed to be a PRIVATE BUS, nor shall any school bus or
any bus used to carry passengers for hire be considered a PRIVATE BUS.
   PRIVATE ROAD OR DRIVEWAY. Every way or place in private ownership used for
vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission
from the owner, but not by other persons.
   RAILROAD. A carrier of persons or property upon cars other than streetcars
operating upon stationary rails.
   RAILROAD SIGN OR SIGNAL. Any sign, signal or device, erected by authority of
a public body or official or by a railroad, intended to give notice of the
presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train.
   RAILROAD TRAIN. A steam engine electric or other motor, with or without cars
coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except street cars.
   RESIDENCE DISTRICT. The territory contiguous to and including a highway not
comprising a business district, when the property on such highway for a
distance of 500 feet or more is in the main improved with residences or
residences and buildings in use for business.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY. The privilege of the immediate use of the highway.
   ROAD TRACTOR. Every motor vehicle designed for drawing other vehicles and
not constructed to carry any load independently or any part of the weight of a
vehicle or load drawn.
   ROADWAY. The portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for
vehicular travel.
   SAFETY ZONE. The area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the
exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or
indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set
apart as a safety zone.
   SCHOOL BUS. Every motor vehicle owned by a public or governmental agency and
operated for the transportation of children to or from school, or privately
owned and operated for compensation for the transportation of children to and
from school.
   SEMI-TRAILER. Every vehicle with or without motive power, other than a pole
trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a
motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and that of its
load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle.
   SIDEWALK. The portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral
lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of
pedestrians.
   SOLID TIRE. Every tire of rubber or other resilient material which does not
depend upon compressed air for the support of the load.
   STOP. Complete cessation of movement.
   STOP, STOPPING or STANDING. Any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether
occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign
or signal.
   STREET or HIGHWAY. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular travel.
   THROUGH HIGHWAY. Every highway or portion thereof at the entrance to which
vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield right-
of-way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign
or a yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this title.
   TRAFFIC. Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, streetcars, vehicles and
other conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for a
purposes of travel.
   TRAILER. Every vehicle with or without motive power other then a pole
trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a
motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the
towing vehicle.
   TRUCK. Every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the
transportation of property.
   TRUCK TRACTOR. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing
other vehicles and not constructed to carry a load other than a part of the
weight of the vehicle and load drawn.
   URBAN DISTRICT. The territory contiguous to and including any street which
is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling houses
situated at intervals of less than 100 feet for a distance of one-fourth of a
mile or more.
   VEHICLE. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or
used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:07)  (Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.08  SIGHT-IMPAIRED CROSSWALK.
   There is hereby created a sight-impaired crosswalk on the north side of the
intersection of Dora Avenue and Main Street in the town. The said sight-
impaired crosswalk shall be four feet in width. The southern boundary line of
the sight-impaired crosswalk shall abut the northern boundary line of Main
Street, and the northern and the southern boundary lines of the sight-impaired
crosswalk shall run parallel with and to the northern boundary line of Main
Street. The sight-impaired crosswalk shall begin on the eastern boundary line
of the Dora Avenue right-of-way and shall extend west across Dora Avenue to its
western boundary line.
(Prior Code, § 4:4:07)  (Ord. 82-18, passed 12-31-1983; Ord. 82-20, passed 12-
31-1982; Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-2-1983; Ord. 84-
2, passed 11-7-1984; Ord. 88-1, passed 1-20-1988; Ord. 88-2, passed 2-17-1988;
Ord. 91-2, passed 4-3-1991; Ord. 93-2, passed 5-5-1993; Ord. 94-1, passed 3-2-
1994; Ord. 95-03, passed 8-2-1995)
§ 70.09  SIGNS.
   For purposes of
Ch. 75, Schd. I,
II and
IV,
Ch. 76, Schd. I and
II, and §
70.08 of this chapter, the Traffic Engineer shall cause signs to be posted in
appropriate places on the streets, alleys and public ways affected by the
traffic and parking schedules of this traffic code.
(Prior Code, § 4:4:08)  (Ord. 82-18, passed 12-31-1983; Ord. 82-20, passed 12-
31-1982; Ord. 82-22, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-2-1983; Ord. 84-
2, passed 11-7-1984; Ord. 88-1, passed 1-20-1988; Ord. 88-2, passed 2-17-1988;
Ord. 91-2, passed 4-3-1991; Ord. 93-2, passed 5-5-1993; Ord. 94-1, passed 3-2-
1994; Ord. 95-03, passed 8-2-1995)
TRAFFIC ENGINEER
§ 70.20  OFFICE ESTABLISHED.
   The Marshal shall serve as Traffic Engineer, in addition to his or her other
functions. The Marshal’s First Deputy shall serve as the Assistant Traffic
Engineer. Neither the Marshal, nor the First Deputy, shall receive additional
compensation in connection with serving as the Traffic Engineer and the
assistant Traffic Engineer.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:01)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.21  GENERAL DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the Traffic Engineer and the assistant Traffic
Engineer to do the following:
   (A)   To determine the installation and maintenance of traffic-control
devices;
   (B)   To conduct engineering analysis of traffic accidents and to devise
remedial measures;
   (C)   To conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions;
   (D)   To plan the operation of traffic on the streets, alleys and highways
of the town;
   (E)   To cooperate with other town officials in the developments of ways and
means to improve traffic conditions; and
   (F)   To carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of
the town.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:02)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.22  REVIEW BY THE TOWN COUNCIL.
   Whenever in the administration of the traffic ordinances of the town, the
Traffic Engineer or the Assistant Traffic Engineer takes action as provided
herein, his or her acts shall be subject to review by the Town Council at any
time within 90 days; however, such acts shall remain in full force and effect
unless remanded, modified or nullified upon such review.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:03)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.23  EMERGENCY AND EXPERIMENTAL REGULATIONS.
   Subject to the consent of the Town Council, the Traffic Engineer and the
Assistant Traffic Engineer is empowered to make regulations necessary to make
effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances and to make and enforce
temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special
conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulations shall remain in
effect for more than 90 days. The Traffic Engineer may test traffic-control
devices under actual conditions of traffic.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:04)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.24  TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES; INSTALLATION; MANUAL; SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Installation of traffic-control devices. Subject to the consent of the
Town Council, the Traffic Engineer shall place and maintain traffic-control
signs, signals and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances to
make effective the provisions of the ordinances, and may place and maintain
such additional traffic-control devices as may be necessary to regulate traffic
under the traffic ordinances of the town or under state law, or to guide or
warn traffic.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:05)
   (B)   Manual and specifications for traffic-control devices. All traffic-
control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and
specifications approved by the state’s Highway Department. All signs and
signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable
be uniform as to type and location throughout the town. All traffic-control
devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or the
traffic ordinance shall be official traffic-control devices. The construction,
design and placement of traffic signs set forth in the Indiana Manual On
Traffic-Control Devices and published by the Department of Highways is
incorporated into this subchapter as required, by I.C. 9-21-2-1.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:06)
(Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.25  SPEED; REGULATION BY TRAFFIC SIGNALS.
   Subject to the consent of the Council, the Traffic Engineer may regulate the
placement of traffic signals, signs and devices so as to permit the movement of
traffic in an orderly and safe manner at speeds slightly at variance from the
speeds otherwise applicable within the district or at intersections, and may
erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:07)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.26  PLAY STREET DESIGNATION.
   Subject to the consent of the Town Council, the Traffic Engineer may declare
any street or part thereof, a play street and to place appropriate signs or
devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:08)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.27  CROSSWALK AND SAFETY ZONE DESIGNATION.
   Subject to the consent of the Town Council, the Traffic Engineer is
authorized:
   (A)   To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon
the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersection where, in his or her
opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at
such other places as he or she may deem necessary; and
   (B)   To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such
places as he or she may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:09)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.28  TRAFFIC LANES; MARKING.
   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of
any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:10)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.29  TURNING MARKERS; PLACEMENT; RESTRICTED TURN SIGNS.
   (A)   Placing of turning markers. The Traffic Engineer is authorized to
place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating
the course to be traveled by vehicles at such intersections.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:11)
   (B)   Placing of restricted turn signs. The Traffic Engineer is authorized
to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a
right, left or U-turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The
making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and
permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on
the signs or such signs may be removed when such turns are permitted.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:12)
(Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.30  ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS.
   Whenever any ordinance of the town designates any one-way street or alley,
the Traffic Engineer shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and
no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs
indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed in every
intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:13)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.31  RESTRICTING DIRECTION OF MOVEMENT ON STREET DURING CERTAIN PERIODS.
   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to determine and designate streets, parts
of streets or specific lanes upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one
direction during one period and the opposite direction during another period of
the day, and shall place and maintain appropriate markings, sign, barriers or
other devices to give notice thereof. The Traffic Engineer may erect signs
temporarily designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular
direction, regardless of the centerline of the roadway.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:14)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.32  STOP AND YIELD SIGNS; ERECTION; SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Whenever the traffic ordinances or any other ordinance of the town
designates and describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the Traffic
Engineer to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street
intersecting such through street or intersecting that portion thereof described
and designated as such by any ordinance of the town unless traffic at any such
intersection is controlled at all times by traffic-control signals. However, at
the intersection of two such through streets or at the intersection of a
through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall
be erected at the approaches of either or both of the streets as may be
determined by the Traffic Engineer upon the basis of an engineering and traffic
study.
   (B)   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to determine and designate
intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than through streets
and may designate any such intersection as a stop intersection or a yield
intersection and erect stop signs or yield signs at one or more entrances to
such intersections.
   (C)   Every stop sign erected pursuant to this section shall bear the word
“stop” in letters not less than eight inches in height, and every yield sign
shall bear the word “yield” in letters not less than seven inches in height.
Such signs shall at nighttime be rendered luminous by steady or flashing
internal illumination, by a fixed floodlight projected on the face of the sign,
or by efficient reflecting elements on the face of the sign. Every stop sign
and every yield sign shall be located as near as practicable at the nearest
line of the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, at the
nearest line of the roadway, in residence and business districts, and at any
place where parked vehicles may frequently obscure the stop or yield signs, the
signs shall be mounted so that their lower edge will be seven feet above the
top of the curb. The left edge of the sign shall be not less than one foot, nor
more than three feet, back from the face of the curb. Where there is a marked
crosswalk on the pavement, the sign shall be erected four feet in advance of
the crosswalk line nearest to approaching traffic.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:15)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.33  PARKING SIGNS; PLACEMENT.
   Whenever, by the traffic ordinances or any other ordinance of the town, any
parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets,
it shall be the duty of the Traffic Engineer to erect appropriate signs giving
notice thereof. No such regulations shall be effective unless the signs are
erected and in place at time of any alleged offense.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:16)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.34  ANGLE PARKING; SIGNS OR MARKINGS.
   (A)   The Traffic Engineer shall determine upon what streets angle parking
shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets. Angle parking shall not
be indicated upon any federal aid or state highway within the town unless the
state’s Highway Department has determined by resolution or order entered in its
minutes that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without
interfering with the free movement of traffic.
   (B)   Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where
traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the
street.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:17)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.35  LOADING OR UNLOADING AT ANGLE TO CURB; PERMIT.
   (A)   Subject to the terms and conditions of ordinances, or the chapters of
this traffic code, the Traffic Engineer is authorized to issue special permits
to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or
unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such
permit.
   (B)   Such permits maybe be issued either to the owner or lessee of real
property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the
privilege as therein stated and authorized herein.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:18)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.36  PARKING ADJACENT TO SCHOOLS PROHIBITED; SIGN PLACEMENT.
   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon
either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such
parking would, in his or her opinion, interfere with traffic or create a
hazardous situation.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:19)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.37  PARKING ON NARROW STREETS PROHIBITED; SIGN PLACEMENT.
   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon
any street when the width of the roadway does not permit parking or travel in
safety.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:20)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.38  STANDING OR PARKING ON ONE-WAY STREETS PROHIBITED; SIGN PLACEMENT.
   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to erect signs upon either or both sides
of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:21)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.39  STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING NEAR HAZARDOUS OR CONGESTED PLACES; SIGN
PLACEMENT.
   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to determine and designate by proper
signs, places not exceeding 150 feet in length in which the stopping, standing
or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would
cause unusual delay to traffic.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:22)  (Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 70.40  CURB LOADING ZONE DESIGNATION; PERMIT.
   (A)   The Traffic Engineer is authorized to determine the location of
passenger and freight curb loading zones, subject to the Town Council, and
shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the
hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:23)
   (B)   (1)   Subject to the approval of the Town Council, the Traffic
Engineer shall not hereafter designate or sign any curb loading zone upon
special request of any person, unless such person makes application for a
permit for such zone and for two signs to indicate the ends of each such zone.
      (2)   The Traffic Engineer upon granting a permit and issuing such signs
shall collect from the applicant and deposit in the town treasury a minimum
service fee of $50 per year or fraction thereof, and may be general regulations
impose conditions for use of such signs, for reimbursement to the town for the
value thereof on the event of their loss or damage, and for their return in the
event of misuse or upon expiration of permit. Every such permit shall expire at
the end of one year.
(Prior Code, § 4:2:24)
(Ord. 82-16, passed 12-31-1982)
PROSECUTION OF TRAFFIC LAWS; PAYMENT OF FINES
§ 70.55  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CASE. A traffic ordinance violation referred for filing by a member of the
Town Marshal’s office.
   TRAFFIC ORDINANCE. An ordinance establishing a speed limit, a one-way
street, the location of a stop or yield sign, the location of other traffic-
control devices, parking, no parking areas or zones, loading and unloading
zones, and snow emergency routes.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:01)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.56  PROSECUTION OF CASE.
   The attorney for the town or the Prosecuting Attorney for the county shall
prosecute alleged violations of traffic ordinances on behalf of the town.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:02)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.57  CLERK OF COUNTY.
   The Clerk of the county or the person designated by the court with the
appropriate jurisdiction over the case shall collect all costs and fines
assessed which arises out of a judgment of a violation of traffic ordinances of
the town.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:03)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.58  PAYMENT OF FINES AND COSTS.
   The Clerk of the county or the person designated by the court with the
appropriate jurisdiction over the case shall pay into the General Fund of the
town the municipal prosecutor’s fee, which fee is set by state statute, plus
the fine for every judgment which is collected in the case. The Clerk of the
county or the person designated by the courts with the appropriate jurisdiction
over the case shall make such payment to the town as soon as is possible
following the collection of any such judgments.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:04)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.59  PAYMENT OF OTHER FEES.
   In addition to the fine and municipal prosecutor’s fee, the violator must
pay a state docket fee, county docket fee, motor vehicle fee and judicial fee
which shall not be paid to the town.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:05)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.60  EXECUTION OF AGREEMENTS.
   In lieu of the attorney for the town prosecuting alleged violations of
traffic ordinances on behalf of the town, the town may enter into a written
agreement with the Prosecutor of the county, which agreement shall provide,
among other things, that the County Prosecutor’s office shall prosecute
violations of town traffic ordinances in return for a reasonable fee to be paid
by the town.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:06)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.61  PAYMENT OF PARKING FINES TO OFFICE OF TOWN’S CLERK-TREASURER.
   Whoever receives a fine for violating any provision of
Ch. 76, Schd. II, of this traffic code may, within 72 hours from the date of
receiving said fine, pay the same at the office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the
town who shall cause a receipt to be issued showing payment of the fine. If
payment is made within the aforementioned 72-hour period, then the fine to be
imposed hereunder shall be $10. If the said sum of $10 is not paid as set forth
within the preceding sentence within the 72-hour period, then the Marshal or
Deputy Marshal shall cause the matter to be filed and docketed in a court of
law and shall proceed with the prosecution thereof as set forth in §§
70.55 through
70.60 of this chapter, and the violator shall upon conviction, be punished with
a minimum fine of $10 and a maximum fine of $1,000 and cost, with each day that
the violation continues being a separate offense which shall subject the
violator to a separate fine as set forth in §
70.99(B) of this chapter and in §
73.99 of this traffic code.
(Prior Code, § 4:3:07)  (Ord. 82-17, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 95-04, passed 10-
18-1995)
§ 70.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-3-8(9) and (10), the maximum fine which may be
imposed under the traffic code is $2,500. Specific fines have been provided
throughout the traffic code, and reference must be made to the specific fine
imposed for a particular violation of a section or provision of the traffic
code.
(Prior Code, § 4:1:08)
   (B)   Any person violating any provision of
Ch. 75 and
76 of this traffic code or of any resolution passed pursuant hereto when
promulgated by the posting of an appropriate traffic sign, upon conviction of
any and for each such violation, shall be punished with a minimum fine of $10
and a maximum penalty of $1,000.
(Prior Code, § 4:4:09)
(Ord. 82-18, passed 12-31-1983; Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-22,
passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-2-1983; Ord. 84-2, passed 11-7-1984;
Ord. 88-1, passed 1-20-1988; Ord. 88-2, passed 2-17-1988; Ord. 91-2, passed 4-

GOLF CARTS
§ 71.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DRIVER’S LICENSE. A valid license to operate a motor vehicle issued by
Indiana or any other state.
   FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY. Liability insurance coverage on a golf cart in an
amount not less than required by state law for motor vehicles operated on
public highways in the state.
   GOLF CART. A vehicle with three or four wheels originally designed for
operation on a golf course and powered by a battery or internal combustion
motor.
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)
§ 71.02  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   The owners or lessees of golf carts shall obtain a permit for the golf cart
from the town before operation on any public right-of-way. The registration
process shall include payment of an annual registration fee of $25 and a
temporary ten-day registration fee of $10 and an inspection by the Police
Department to verify the golf cart is insured and is properly equipped as
required by §§
71.04 and
71.05 of this chapter. Decals reflecting a valid registration permit must be
visibly affixed to each registered golf cart in accordance with requirements of
the Police Department.
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.03  OPERATOR; DRIVER’S LICENSE.
   Only persons holding a valid state driver’s license may operate a golf cart
on any public right-of- way.
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.04  FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   The financial ability of the owner, lessee or operator notwithstanding, the
golf cart must be covered by liability insurance in an amount not less that
that provided by state statues for motor vehicles operated on public
thoroughfares in the state. Written proof of financial responsibility must be
available either on the golf cart or carried by the operator at all times.
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)
§ 71.05  EQUIPMENT.
   All golf carts must be equipped with efficient brakes, reliable steering and
safe tires; and operational head lamps and tail lamps are only required after
sunset and before sunrise. All golf carts must be equipped with a slow moving
vehicle placard, prominently displayed on the rear of the golf cart. Placards
shall remain unobstructed at all times during golf cart operation. All required
equipment is subject to inspection and approval by the Police Department at any
time.
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.06  OPERATION REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Golf carts may only be driven on the roadway or alley ways. Golf cart
operation is prohibited on sidewalks, walking paths, grass rights-of-way, any
private property without the owners consent and on town park property, except
areas designated for vehicular parking.
   (B)   Golf carts may not be operated at a speed greater than 20 mph.
   (C)   The operator of the golf cart shall comply with all traffic rules and
regulations adopted by the state and the town which govern the operation of
motor vehicles.
   (D)   The operator of any golf cart shall pull over in a safe area whenever
possible to allow any overtaking motor vehicle to pass so as not to impede the
normal flow of traffic.
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.07  OCCUPANTS.
   (A)   The number of occupants in a golf cart shall be limited to the number
of persons for whom factory seating is installed and provided on the golf cart.
   (B)   The operator and all occupants shall be seated in the golf cart and no
part of the body of the operator or occupant(s) shall extend outside the
perimeter of the golf cart while the golf cart is being operated.
   (C)   No occupant of a golf cart shall sit upon another during operation.
   (D)   Operators of any golf cart may not carry child passengers less than
four years of age unless accompanied by the child’s parent.
   (E)   The operator of the golf cart is responsible for the safety of its
occupant(s).
(Ord. 2013-03, passed 7-15-2013)  Penalty, see §
71.99
SKATEBOARDS AND OTHER WHEELED TOY VEHICLES AND DEVICES
§ 71.20  REGULATION OF SKATEBOARDS.
   No person riding on or by means of a skateboard, coaster, scooter or similar
wheeled toy vehicle or device shall park, stand or use the same upon the
streets, roads, sidewalks, grassy areas and public parking areas located within
the following public right-of-way in the town:
   (A)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as Main
Street where the same is located in the town (from Scherer Avenue to S.R. 19);
   (B)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Shaffer Street from the intersection of Main Street and Shaffer Street to the
south side of the intersection of Shaffer Street and Franklin Avenue;
   (C)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Hamilton Avenue from the intersection of Shaffer Street and Hamilton Avenue to
the intersection of Hamilton Avenue and S.R. 19;
   (D)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Madison Avenue from the intersection of Shaffer Street and Madison Avenue to
the intersection of Madison Avenue and S.R. 19;
   (E)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Marion Avenue from the intersection of Shaffer Street and Marion Avenue to the
intersection of Marion Avenue and S.R. 19;
   (F)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Howard Avenue from the intersection of Shaffer Street and Howard Avenue to the
intersection of Howard Avenue and S.R. 19;
   (G)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Broadway Avenue from the Intersection of Shaffer Street and Broadway Avenue to
the intersection of Broadway Avenue and S.R. 19; and
   (H)   All of the area within the public right-of-way commonly known as
Franklin Avenue from the intersection of Shaffer Street and Franklin Avenue to
the intersection of Franklin Avenue and S.R. 19.
(Prior Code, § 5:8:01)  (Ord. 2005-14, passed 11-21-2005)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.21  PUBLIC NUISANCE.
   It is hereby declared a public nuisance and, therefore, a violation of this
section to ride or operate a skateboard, coaster, scooter or any similar
wheeled toy vehicle or device on the streets, sidewalks, grassy areas, ramps
and public parking areas within the rights-of-way, roads, streets and highways
set forth hereinabove.
(Prior Code, § 5:8:02)  (Ord. 2005-14, passed 11-21-2005)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.22  TEMPORARILY HOLDING SKATEBOARDS.
   Any skateboard, coaster, scooter or other similar wheeled toy vehicle or
device operated in violation of this section may be temporarily held by the
town to abate the nuisance.
(Prior Code, § 5:8:03)  (Ord. 2005-14, passed 11-21-2005)
§ 71.23  EXCEPTION FOR SPECIAL EVENTS.
   An exception to this subchapter exists for special events, parades or
similar activities where a right-of-way use or other applicable permit from the
town is in effect for the activity.
(Prior Code, § 5:8:06)  (Ord. 2005-14, passed 11-21-2005)
SNOWMOBILES
§ 71.35  AUTHORITY.
   This subchapter is made by the Council pursuant to the authority granted it
by I.C. 14-16-1-1 et seq.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:01)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)
§ 71.36  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   HIGHWAY, STREET, ALLEY or RIGHT-OF-WAY. The entire width between the
boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open
to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel.
   OFF-ROAD VEHICLE. A motor driven vehicle capable of cross county travel,
without benefit of a road or trail, on or immediately over land, water, snow,
ice, marsh, swampland or other natural terrain. It includes, but is not limited
to, a multi-wheel drive or low pressure tire vehicle, amphibious machine,
ground-effect air cushion vehicle or other means of transportation deriving
motive power from a source other than muscle of wind. It does not include a
farm vehicle being used for farming, a vehicle used for military or law
enforcement purposes, construction, mining or other industrial related vehicles
used in performance of its common function or a registered aircraft and does
not include for registration any other vehicle properly registered by the
Bureau of Motor Vehicles, and any water craft which is registered pursuant to
state statutes.
   OPERATE. To ride in or on and to be in actual physical control of the
operation of a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle.
   OPERATOR. Any person who operates or is in actual physical control of a
snowmobile or an off-road vehicle.
   OWNER. Any person, other than a lien-holder, having the property in or title
to a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle entitled to the use or possession
thereof.
   PERSON. An individual, partnership, corporation, the state and any of its
agencies or subdivisions, and any body of person whether incorporated or not.
   SNOWMOBILE. Any motor driven vehicle designed for travel primarily on snow
or ice of a type which utilizes sled type runners or skis, or an endless belt
tread or any combination of these or other similar means of contact with the
surface upon which it is operated.
   VEHICLE. A snowmobile or an off-road vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:02)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)
§ 71.37  SNOWMOBILE ROUTES.
   (A)   No person shall operate a snowmobile or other off-road vehicles on any
streets, alleys or other public right-of-way in the town, except on those
streets and during those hours specifically identified and set forth in
divisions (B) and (C) below.
   (B)   After signs have been posted by the Traffic Engineer along the
following streets identifying them as a snowmobile route, the same may be used
by operators of snowmobiles for the purpose of reaching a road, street, highway
or other real property located outside of the municipal boundaries of the town
during those hours stated herein.

   (C)   Operators of snowmobiles shall be given limited access during the

(Prior Code, § 4:9:03)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.38  OPERATION ON DESIGNATED ROUTES WITHIN THE TOWN.
   (A)   A person shall not operate a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle on the
designated routes within the town: at a rate of speed greater than is
reasonable and proper having due regard for conditions then existing; provided,
however, in no event shall a person operate a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle
in excess of 20 mph.
   (B)   A person operating a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle shall be
subject to and shall obey all traffic and parking laws of the town and shall
obey all traffic devices, markings and signs, including stop and yield signs,
posted by the town.
   (C)   A person operating a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle shall yield the
right-of-way to pedestrians and to all other traffic using the streets,
sidewalks, alleys and rights-of-way located within the town.
   (D)   A person shall not operate a snowmobile or an off-road vehicle on any
street, road, alley or other public way in the town, except on the streets
specifically designated and during those hours listed in §
71.37 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:04)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)  Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.39  APPLICATION OF STATE STATUTES.
   Except to the extent modified by specific terms and provisions of this
subchapter, the provisions of I.C. 14-1-3-1 et seq. and of 14-1.5-3-1 et seq.
that are permitted to be incorporated into this subchapter are hereby fully
incorporated herein by reference. The Marshal and his or her deputies shall
enforce this subchapter and the state statutes which regulate and govern the
use and operation of snowmobiles or off-road vehicles. This subchapter is not
intended to duplicate or replace I.C. 14-16-1-1 et seq., but is intended to
supplement the laws of the state and to impose certain minimum requirements to
protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the town. However,
the penalties contained in I.C. 14-16-1-1 et seq. are not incorporated into
this subchapter and shall not be considered a part hereof.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:05)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)
§ 71.40  LIABILITY AND DUTY OF OPERATORS.
   The town shall owe no duty of care to keep the roads, streets, alleys and
other public ways safe for entry or use by persons operating, using or riding
in snowmobiles or other off-road vehicles, or to give any warning of a
dangerous condition, use, structure or activity on such roads, streets, alleys,
sidewalks or other public ways to such persons. Nothing in this subchapter
shall be construed to create or increase a duty of care or ground of liability
for injury to persons or property, or relieve any person using a snowmobile or
an off-road vehicle from any obligation which he or she may have to exercise
care in the use of the streets authorized in §
71.37 of this chapter, or from the legal consequences of failure to employ such
care.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:06)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)
§ 71.41  AUTHORIZED USE BY A POLICE OFFICER.
   Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, a duly
constituted law enforcement officer of the town, county or the state may
authorize use of a vehicle on the public highways, streets and right-of-way
within the town during emergencies when conventional motor vehicles cannot be
used for transportation due to snow or other extreme highway conditions.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:07)  (Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985)
§ 71.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   (1)   Operators of golf carts are subject to citations for violations
of any provision of §§
71.01 through
71.07 of this chapter.
      (2)   Violations by the owner or operator of any provision of §§
71.01 through
71.07 of this chapter may be cause for revocation or suspension of the owner’s
permit for the golf cart. It shall be the sole determination of the town’s
Police Department whether any violation or a series of violations constitutes a
revocation or suspension and the duration of said action.
      (3)   In addition to the penalty provided in division (B)(1) above, any
person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of §§
71.01 through
71.07 of this chapter may be prosecuted in court and shall, upon conviction, be
punished with a minimum fine of $50 and a maximum fine not exceeding $2,500. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which a
violation occurs or continues.
      (4)   In addition to the penalties provided in divisions (B)(1) and (B)
(2) above, the town is empowered to obtain a restraining order and/or a
permanent injunction against any person, firm, corporation or any other entity
that show to be in violation of §§
71.01 through
71.07 of this chapter. A person against whom the town recovers a judgment shall
pay costs of the court action and the town’s attorney’s fees.
   (C)   (1)   Any person, upon conviction for a first or second violation of
§§
71.20 through
71.23 of this chapter, shall be liable for a fine up to $100 for each such
violation.
(Prior Code, § 5:8:04)
      (2)   Any person, upon conviction for a third or subsequent violation of
§§
71.20 through
71.23 of this chapter, may be liable for a fine up to $500.
(Prior Code, § 5:8:05)
   (D)   Any person who violates any provision of §§
71.35 through
71.41 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine
of $10 and a maximum fine of $200, in addition to costs. Each incident shall
constitute a separate violation under §§
71.35 through
71.41 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 4:9:01)
(Ord. 82-42, passed 2-2-1985; Ord. 2005-14, passed 11-21-2005; Ord. 2013-03,
passed 7-15-2013)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 72.01  U-TURNS.
   The driver of a vehicle shall not make a U-turn on any street, alley or
public way in the town where signs giving notice have been posted prohibiting
U-turns, and not vehicle shall be turned so as to proceed in the opposite
direction upon said streets, alleys and public ways.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:01)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.02  THROUGH STREETS.
   When signs are erected giving notice that a street has been designated a
through street, drivers of vehicles shall stop or yield at every intersection
or entrance thereto. Every driver of a vehicle shall stop or yield in obedience
to any such sign before entering such intersection, except when directed to
proceed by a police officer or traffic-control signal.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:02)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.03  UNUSUAL NOISES.
   (A)   No person shall sound any horn, signal device or other attachment on a
vehicle, except as a necessary warning of danger to persons or property.
   (B)   No person shall cause and/or create any grating, screeching, grinding
or squealing noise, or any loud reports, shots or other loud and/or unusual
noises in the use of, or in the operation of motor vehicles or appurtenances
attached thereto.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:03)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.04  PROCESSIONS.
   No procession or parade composed of persons and/or vehicles or animals,
excepting the forces of the United States army or navy, the military forces of
the state, the forces of the Police and Fire Departments and a funeral
procession, shall occupy, march or proceed along the street, except in
accordance with a permit issued by the Marshal’s office along with the consent
of the Council.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:04)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.05  DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS.
   Drivers of vehicles shall not drive within or upon any sidewalk area, except
where it is necessary to enter a permanent or temporary driveway.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:05)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.06  DRIVING ON PLAY STREETS.
   Whenever signs are erected giving notice that a street or alley or part
thereof has been designated as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle
upon any such street, alley or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles
having business thereon or whose residence are within such closed area, and
then any driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such
street, alley or portion thereof.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:06)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.07  OPERATION ON STREETS WHERE MOVEMENT RESTRICTED.
   No person shall operate any vehicle in violation of markings, signs,
barriers or other devices placed in accordance with this traffic code
indicating that traffic is to proceed in only one direction during certain
periods.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:07)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.08  BICYCLES.
   In addition to the provision set forth in I.C. 9-21-11-1 et seq., as the
same applies to bicycles, the following shall also be applicable.
   (A)   All persons located in the town engaged in the business of buying and
selling new or used bicycles shall make a monthly report to the Marshal giving
the name and address of the person from or to whom each bicycle is purchased or
sold, and a description and frame number of the bicycle.
   (B)   A rental agency located in the town shall not rent or offer any
bicycle for rent unless the same is equipped by such agency with lights,
audible warning devices and other safety equipment required by I.C. 9-21-11-
8 et seq.
   (C)   Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a
street or roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the
street or roadway.
   (D)   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is
reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing.
   (E)   The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building
shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any
alleyway, driveway and path or walkway, yield the right-of-way to all
pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area and, upon entering the
street or roadway, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on
the street or roadway.
   (F)   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the
roadway against the curb, upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle,
against a building or at the curb in such a manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic.
   (G)   The Marshal and/or his or her deputies shall have the authority to
inspect bicycles for the purpose of ascertaining whether the same are in safe
mechanical condition and whether said bicycles have lights audible warning
devices, and other safety equipment required by the laws of the state.
Furthermore, the Marshal and his or her deputies are authorized to conduct
bicycle safety classes for riders.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:08)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.09  ROLLER SKATES.
   No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy
vehicle, go-cart or similar device, shall go upon any roadway or street, except
while crossing a street on a crosswalk. When so crossing, such person shall be
granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable
to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street which has been set
aside as a play street.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:09)  (Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTES
§ 72.20  SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTES.
   The Traffic Engineer shall post signs along the following named street(s)
located in the town which declares the same to be a snow emergency route, and
said snow emergency route shall be effective at the time specified herein and
when signs are erected giving notice thereof.
 
Street      Between                    Side
Main Street S.R. 19 and Scherer Avenue North and south sides
 
(Prior Code, § 4:8:01)  (Ord. 82-19, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 72.21  NO PARKING ALONG ROUTE.
   (A)   When two or more inches of snow or other forms of freezing
precipitation accumulates on the street(s) described in §
72.20 of this chapter, there shall be no parking on either side of said street
(s) until the snow or other forms of freezing precipitation has been removed by
the town.
   (B)   REMOVAL or REMOVED, as used herein, means the plowing of said street
(s) from curb to curb by the town.
(Prior Code, § 4:8:02)  (Ord. 82-19, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.22  PURPOSE OF SUBCHAPTER.
   The purpose of this subchapter is to expedite snow removal on said street(s)
and to facilitate the movement of traffic thereon.
(Prior Code, § 4:8:03)  (Ord. 82-19, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 72.23  DUTY OF OWNER OR LESSEE TO REMOVE VEHICLE FROM A SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTE.
   Whenever two or more inches of snow or other forms of freezing precipitation
accumulates on the street(s) described in §
72.20 of this chapter, all vehicles shall be immediately removed from said
street(s) by the owner or lessee of said vehicle and/or by the person who has
control or possession of said vehicle. The word VEHICLE, used herein, refers to
an automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semi- trailer, tractor, bus, school
bus, recreational vehicle or motorized bicycle.
(Prior Code, § 4:8:04)  (Ord. 82-19, passed 12-31-1982)  Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   (1)   Any person who violates any of the provisions of §§
72.01 through
72.07 of this chapter, and upon conviction of any and for each such violation,
shall be punished with a minimum fine of $10 and a maximum fine of $1,000. Each
day the act (violation) continues shall constitute a separate violation.
      (2)   Any person who violates any of the provisions of §§
72.08 and
72.09 of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than $25 or by
the impounding of the offender’s bicycle, roller skates, coaster, toy vehicle,
go-cart or similar device for a period not to exceed 30 days, or both.
(Prior Code, § 4:6:10)
   (C)   (1)   Any person who owns, leases or controls a vehicle and who fails
and/or refuses to remove the vehicle as prescribed in §
72.23 of this chapter, commits a violation of §§
72.20 through
72.23 of this chapter, and upon conviction of any and for each such violation,
shall be punished with a minimum fine of $10 and a maximum fine of $1,000. Each
day the act (violation) continues shall constitute a separate violation.
      (2)   In addition to the foregoing penalty, the Town Marshal and his or
her deputies are empowered to remove any vehicle found in violation of §§
72.20 through
72.23 of this chapter. For the purpose of enforcing §§
72.20 through
72.23 of this chapter, the town may enter into a towing contract for the
purpose of removing a vehicle found parked on the street(s) listed in §
72.20 of this chapter and found to be in violation of the terms and conditions
of §§
72.20 through
72.23 of this chapter. Any and all costs incurred by the town in removing a
vehicle pursuant to §§
72.20 through
72.23 of this chapter shall be added to the fine imposed in division (C)(1)
above, and said costs shall not be waived or suspended.
      (3)   In the event the Marshal, his or her deputies, a towing service,
the town or an employee or an agent of the town removes a vehicle pursuant to
division (C)(2) above, they shall not be liable for loss or damage to the
vehicle or parts occurring during its removal.
(Prior Code, § 4:8:05)
(Ord. 82-19, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-21, passed 12-31-1982)

§ 73.01  APPLICATION.
   In addition to the provisions set forth in I.C. 9-21-16-1 regulating
stopping, standing and parking of vehicles on streets, highways, alleys and
other public ways, this chapter shall apply to the stopping, standing and
parking of vehicles on streets, highway, alleys and other public ways located
within the town as indicated herein.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:01)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)
§ 73.02  ANGLE PARKING.
   (A)   Upon those streets which have been signed or marked by the Traffic
Engineer for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than
at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or
makings. The vehicle must enter the parking space with a forward movement.
   (B)   Wherever angle parking is permitted, no person shall park or stand a
vehicle with a total length in excess of 20 feet.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:02)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.03  INDIVIDUAL PARKING SPACES.
   Where individual parking spaces are designated and marked off in accordance
with the title, vehicles shall be parked entirely within the area designated by
such marking, and it shall be unlawful to park any standard size vehicle across
any such marking.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:03)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.04  STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING OF VEHICLE WITHIN STREET OR ALLEY
PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park a vehicle within a street or alley in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of
the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall
stop, stand or park a vehicle within a street or alley in such position as to
block the driveway entrance to any abutting property.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:04)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.05  REPAIRING AND THE LIKE OF VEHICLE ON STREET PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon any such street or highway for the
principal purpose of:
   (A)   Displaying such vehicle for sale; and
   (B)   Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs
necessitated by an emergency.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:05)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.06  LOADING AND UNLOADING PASSENGERS.
   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of
time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any
place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations
applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period
not to exceed five minutes.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:06)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.07  LOADING AND UNLOADING FREIGHT.
   (A)   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or
length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup
and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone
during house when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect, except
for the loading or unloading of passengers with a five-minute time limit.
   (B)   In no case shall the stop for loading and unlading of materials exceed
30 minutes.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:07)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.08  CONDITIONS OF LOADING PERMIT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person who has been granted a permit to load or
unload at an angle to the curb to violate any of the special terms of
conditions of any such permit.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:08)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.09  PARKING DURING PARADES AND THE LIKE.
   (A)   During any public parade, assembly or demonstration upon the streets,
or during an emergency, officers of the Marshal’s office may prohibit parking
upon any street to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians.
   (B)   Any owner, driver or operator of any vehicle, when called upon by a
police officer at any such time to remove the same, shall do so immediately.
   (C)   If such owner driver or operator cannot be found, any police officer
may himself or herself remove such vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:09)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.10  RESTRICTED PARKING AND THE LIKE DURING CERTAIN HOURS.
   When appropriate signs are erected upon a street or alley indicating that
stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle is prohibited during certain hours,
no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in violation of the regulations
indicated on such signs on any day, except Sundays and holidays.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:10)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)  Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.11  STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING RESTRICTIONS CURRENTLY IN FORCE.
   Any and all stopping, standing and parking restrictions, rules and
regulations currently in force in the town and which are duly posted by signs
or duly marked shall remain in full force and effect from and after the passage
of this chapter, and said stopping, standing and parking restriction, rules and
regulations currently in force in the town on those streets, roadways, alleys
and public ways which are duly posted by signs or other marking are fully
incorporated into this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:11)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)
§ 73.12  AMENDING, MODIFYING AND THE LIKE OF THIS CHAPTER.
   From and after the date of the passage of this chapter, any request to
amend, add to, modify or delete passenger curb loading zones, freight curb
loading zones, angle parking and/or parking in streets and alleys shall require
the consent of the Council, except in those circumstances and cases set forth
in
Ch. 76 of this traffic code.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:12)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)
§ 73.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, and upon conviction
of any and for each such violation, shall be punished with a minimum fine of
$10 and a maximum fine of $1,000. Each day the act (violation) continues shall
constitute a separate violation.
(Prior Code, § 4:5:13)  (Ord. 82-20, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 82-51, passed 11-
2-1983)
CHAPTER 74:  ABANDONED VEHICLES
Section
   
74.01   Purpose
   
74.02   Definitions
   
74.03   Exceptions
   
74.04   Responsibility of owner
   
74.05   Vehicles in possession of person other than owner
   
74.06   Removal of abandoned vehicles
   
74.07   Disposal of abandoned vehicles
   
74.08   [Reserved]
   
74.09   Towing contracts
   
74.10   Liability for loss or damage
Statutory reference:
   Related provisions, see I.C. 9-22-1-1 et seq., 9-18-12 and 9-22-1 et seq.
§ 74.01  PURPOSE.
   The Town Council finds that abandoned vehicles are a public nuisance and a
safety and health hazard.  The Marshals’ office is given the responsibility for
removal, storage and disposal of abandoned vehicles.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:01)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 74.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED VEHICLE.
      (1)   A vehicle located on public property illegally;
      (2)   A vehicle left on public property continuously without being moved
for 72 hours;
      (3)   A vehicle that has remained on private property without the consent
of the owner or person in control of that property for more than 72 hours;
      (4)   A vehicle from which there has been moved removed the engine,
transmission or differential or that is otherwise partially dismantled or
inoperable and left of public property;
      (5)   A vehicle that has been removed by an authorized towing service
upon request of an officer enforcing a statue or ordinance other than this
chapter if the vehicle once impounded is not claimed or redeemed by the owner
or his or her agent within 15 days of its removal; and/or
      (6)   A vehicle that is six or more years old and mechanically
inoperable, and is left on private property continuously in a location visible
from public property for more than 30 days.
   AUTHORIZED TOWING SERVICE. A business that engages in moving or removing
disabled vehicles and, once removed, to store or impound vehicles, and that has
been requested by the Town Marshal or his or her deputies to tow vehicles.
   AUTOMOBILE SCRAPYARD. A business organized for the purpose of scrap metal
processing, automobile wrecking or operating a junkyard.
   BUREAU. The Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
   OFFICER. The Town Marshal or one of his or her deputies.
   OWNER. The last known record titleholder of a vehicle according to the
records of the Bureau under I.C. 9-14.
   PARTS. All components of a vehicle that as assembled do not constitute a
complete vehicle.
   PRIVATE PROPERTY. All property other than public property.
   PUBLIC PROPERTY. A public right-of-way, street, highway, alley, park or
other state, county or municipal property.
   VEHICLE. An automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semi-trailer, tractor,
bus, school bus, recreational vehicle or motorized bicycle.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:02)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 2017-02, passed 6-
5-2017)
§ 74.03  EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter does not apply to:
   (A)   A vehicle in operable condition specifically adapted or constructed
for operation on privately- owned raceways;
   (B)   A vehicle stored as the property of a member of the armed forces of
the United States who is on active duty assignment;
   (C)   A vehicle located on a vehicle sale lot or at a commercial vehicle
servicing facility; provided, however, that, no mechanically inoperable vehicle
shall be left on a vehicle sale lot or at a commercial vehicle servicing
facility in a location visible form private or public property for more than 30
days;
   (D)   A vehicle located upon property licensed or zoned as an automobile
scrapyard; or
   (E)   A vehicle registered and licensed under I.C. 9-18-12 as an antique
vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:03)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 74.04  RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER.
   The owner of an abandoned vehicle is responsible for the abandonment and is
liable, to the extent of the market value of the vehicle, for all of the costs
incidental to the removal, storage and disposal of the vehicle or its parts.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:04)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 74.05  VEHICLES IN POSSESSION OF PERSON OTHER THAN OWNER.
   (A)   (1)   When an officer discovers a vehicle in the possession of a
person other than the owner and the person cannot establish his or her right to
the possession of that vehicle, the vehicle shall be taken to and stored in a
suitable place.
      (2)   The Bureau shall be notified within 72 hours of the location and
description of the vehicle. Upon receipt of notification, the Bureau shall
cause a search to be made to determine and notify the owner.
   (B)   If the owner of the vehicle cannot be determined, the Bureau shall
declare the vehicle abandoned and provide for its disposal in accordance with
this chapter.
   (C)   If the proper identified owner or lienholder appears at the site of
storage before disposal of the vehicle or parts and pays all proper costs
incurred against it at that time, when the vehicle or parts shall be released.
A copy of the release of all vehicle or parts shall be sent to the Bureau. The
release must contain the owner or lienholder’s signature, name, address,
vehicle or parts description, costs and date of release.
   (D)   If the vehicle is not released to the owner or lienholder, the Bureau
shall declare the vehicle abandoned and provide for disposal in accordance with
this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:05)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 2017-02, passed 6-
5-2017)
§ 74.06  REMOVAL OF ABANDONED VEHICLES.
   (A)   An officer who finds a vehicle or parts believed to be abandoned shall
attach in a prominent place a notice tag containing the following information:
      (1)   The date, time, officer’s name, Town Police Department and address
and telephone number to contact for information;
      (2)   The vehicle or parts are considered abandoned;
      (3)   The vehicle or parts will be removed after 72 hours;
      (4)   The owner will be held responsible for all costs incidental to the
removal, storage and disposal and, if not paid, the owner’s registration
privileges will be suspended on that car; and
      (5)   The owner may avoid costs by removal of the vehicle or parts within
72 hours.
   (B)   If the tagged vehicle or parts are not removed within that 72-hour
period, the officer shall prepare a written abandoned vehicle report of the
vehicle or parts, including information on the condition, missing parts and
other pertinent facts describing the condition of the vehicle. Photographs
shall be taken to describe the condition of the vehicle or parts.
   (C)   If, in the opinion of the officer, the market value of the abandoned
vehicle or parts is $100 or more, the officer, before placing a notice tag on
the vehicle or parts, shall make a reasonable effort to ascertain the owner or
person who may be in control of the vehicle or parts. After 72 hours, the
officer shall require the vehicle or parts to be towed to a storage area.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:06)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 2017-02, passed 6-
5-2017)
§ 74.07  DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED VEHICLES.
   (A)   Within 72 hours after removal of an abandoned vehicle to a storage
area under this chapter, the Marshal’s office shall prepare and forward to the
Bureau an abandoned vehicle report containing a description of the vehicle
including the make, model, engine number, if any, identification number and the
number of the license plate, and request that the Bureau advise the Marshal’s
office of the name and most recent mailing address of the owner and any
lienholder.
   (B)   The Bureau shall dispose of the vehicle in accordance with I.C. 9-22-
1-13.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:07)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982)
§ 74.08  [RESERVED].
§ 74.09  TOWING CONTRACTS.
   The Marshal’s office may utilize reputable towing companies to facilitate
the removal of abandoned vehicles, parts, or vehicles declared public nuisance.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:09)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 2017-02, passed 6-
5-2017)
§ 74.10  LIABILITY FOR LOSS OR DAMAGE.
   Neither the owner, lessee or occupant of the property from which an
abandoned vehicle or parts are removed, nor the Marshal’s office or authorized
towing service is liable for loss or damage to the vehicle or parts occupying
during its removal, storage or disposition.
(Prior Code, § 4:7:10)  (Ord. 82-15, passed 12-31-1982; Ord. 2017-02, passed 6-
5-2017)

SCHEDULE IV. ONE-WAY STREETS.
   The Traffic Engineer shall post “one-way” street signs on the following
named streets, alleys and public ways located within the town, and all vehicles
traveling said street, alleys and public ways posted “one-way” shall travel in
the direction indicated on the signs, and no vehicle shall travel in the
opposite direction.

of the traffic or parking schedules of this traffic code or of any resolution
past pursuant hereto when promulgated by the posting of an appropriate traffic
sign, upon conviction of any and for each such violation, shall be punished
with a minimum fine of $10 and a maximum fine of $1,000.
(Ord. 98-02, passed 4-20-1998)

Section
