EXHIBITIONS
§ 112.01  AUTHORITY.
   This subchapter is made by the Town Council pursuant to the authority
granted it by I.C. 36-1-4-11, 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-3, 36-1-6-4, 36-5-2-9, 36-8-2-4,
36-8-2-8, 36-8-2-9, 36-8-2-10 and 36-8-2-11.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:01)  (Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 112.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall sponsor, present or give any
exhibition, theatrical performance, show, circus, fair, conventions, sporting
events, menagerie, carnival or sideshow without first obtaining a license to do
so as required in this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:02)  (Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.03  LICENSE APPLICATION; ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation desiring a license to engage in an
activity specified in §
112.02 of this chapter shall file a written application, together with the fee
and deposit prescribed in §
112.04 of this chapter with the Clerk-Treasurer, listing the name and address
of the applicant and that of each officer, partner or business associate and
the nature of and intended location of the activity to be licensed. The Clerk-
Treasurer shall forward the license application to the Town Council for its
review.
   (B)   If the Town Council is satisfied that the location is suitable for the
purpose of the intended activity, that it will safely accommodate the patrons,
that the nature of the performance or exhibition will not be in violation of
any law or ordinance and that the use of the location will not put a burden
upon the Police and Fire Department, the Town Council may authorize the Clerk-
Treasurer to issue the license.
   (C)   The Town Council may impose conditions and restrictions to ensure the
safety of the public in connection with the issuance of the license.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:03)  (Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 112.04  LICENSE FEE AND DEPOSIT.
   The fee for performing any activity specified in §
112.02 of this chapter shall be $25 for each day or part thereof. In addition,
the town may order the deposit of a cash bond of not more than $1,000,
conditioned upon the restoration and cleaning up of the location of the
activity in a manner satisfactory to the Town Council. In the event the
location is so restored and cleaned up, the deposit shall be returned;
otherwise, the deposit shall be forfeited to the town.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:04)  (Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 112.05  INSURANCE; TERMS OF CERTIFICATE.
   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall conduct, hold, present or sponsor
any exhibition, theatrical performance, show, circus, fair, convention,
sporting event, menagerie, carnival or sideshow without first obtaining a
certificate of insurance as set forth in division (B) below and filing the same
with the town’s Clerk-Treasurer.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:05)
   (B)   The certificate of insurance shall be issued by a responsible
insurance company licensed to do an insurance business in the state, and shall
be conditioned for the payment of all damages which may be caused either to a
person or persons and to property, in an amount approved by the Town Council
and its President, by reason of the licensed display, and arising from any acts
of the licensee, his or her agents, employees or independent contractors
thereof.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:06)
(Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 112.06  EXEMPTION.
   No license under this subchapter shall be required for public school
entertainment, lecture courses or any other exhibition for the benefit of any
benevolent, religious or non-profit society which are established and located
in the town.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:07)  (Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)
FIREWORKS DISPLAYS
§ 112.20  AUTHORITY.
   This subchapter is made by the Town Council pursuant to the authority
granted it by I.C. 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-8-2-4, 36-8-2-9 and 36-8-2-10.
(Prior Code, § 6:8:01)  (Ord. 82-30, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 112.21  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall undertake, hold or conduct a fireworks
display without first obtaining a license from the town.
   (A)   The license shall be acquired from the office of the Clerk-Treasurer
after the Town Council and its President have reviewed and have authorized the
issuance of the same.
   (B)   The license fee shall be $25 and the license shall be valid only on
the day or evening that the display is held.
   (C)   The Town Council and its President may approve the license and may
impose conditions and restrictions to ensure the safety of the public in
connection with the issuance of the license.
(Prior Code, § 6:8:02)  (Ord. 82-30, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.22  CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE REQUIRED; TERMS.
   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall conduct a public display of
fireworks within the town without first obtaining a certificate of insurance as
set forth in division (B) below and filing the certificate with the town’s
Clerk-Treasurer.
(Prior Code, § 6:8:03)
   (B)   The certificate of insurance shall be issued by a responsible
insurance company licensed to do an insurance business in the state and shall
be conditioned for the payment of all damages which may be caused either to a
person or persons in an amount of $100,000 and to property in an amount of
$100,000, by reason of the licensed display, and arising from any acts of the
licensee, his or her agents, employees or subcontractors.
(Prior Code, § 6:8:04)
(Ord. 82-30, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 112.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   (1)   Whoever shall violate or fail to comply with any of the
provisions of §§
112.01 through
112.06 of this chapter or shall violate or fail to comply with any order or
regulation made hereunder shall be fined not less than $5, nor more than
$1,000. The payment of such a penalty shall not excuse the violation or permit
it to continue, nor shall such payment be held to prevent the enforced
correction of the prohibited conditions by legal and injunctive remedies. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which
such violation occurs or continues.
      (2)   In addition to the other penalties and remedies provided herein and
pursuant to the authority granted the town under I.C. 36-1-6-2 and 36-1-6-4,
the Marshal and other officers and employees of the town may enter onto real
property where a condition violating any term or condition of §§
112.01 through
112.06 of this chapter exists and take appropriate action to bring the property
into compliance with §§
112.01 through
112.06 of this chapter; provided, however, before action to bring compliance
may be taken, all persons holding a substantial interest in the property must
be given a reasonable opportunity to bring the property into compliance with §§
112.01 through
112.06 of this chapter. If action to bring compliance is taken by the town, the
expenses involved shall be made a lien against the property.
(Prior Code, § 6:4:08)
   (C)   (1)   Whoever shall violate or fail to comply with any of the
provisions of §§
112.20 through
112.22 of this chapter, or shall violate or fail to comply with any order or
regulation made hereunder, shall be fined not less than $5, nor more than
$1,000. The payment of a fine shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue, nor shall such payment be held to prevent the enforced correction of
the prohibited conditions by legal and injunctive remedies. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which such violation
occurs or continues.
      (2)   In addition to the other penalties and remedies provided herein and
pursuant to the authority granted the town under I.C. 36-1-6-2 and 36-1-6-4,
the Marshal and other officers and employees of the town may enter onto real
property where a condition violating any term or condition of §§
112.20 through
112.22 of this chapter exists and take appropriate action to bring the property
into compliance with §§
112.20 through
112.22 of this chapter; provided, however, before action to bring compliance
may be taken, all persons holding a substantial interest in the property must
be given a reasonable opportunity to bring the property into compliance with §§
112.20 through
112.22 of this chapter. If action to bring compliance is taken by the town, the
expenses involved may be made a lien against the property.
(Prior Code, § 6:8:05)
(Ord. 82-30, passed 2-2-1983; Ord. 82-32, passed 2-2-1983)

1-2-15, 36-1-4-11, 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-8-2-4, 36-8-2-8 and 36-8-2-10
   Pawnbrokers, secondhand dealers; related provisions, see I.C. 36-1-4-11, 36-

   State Pawnbroking Law, see I.C. 28-7-5-1 et seq.
PAWNBROKERS AND SECONDHAND DEALERS
§ 113.01  AUTHORITY.
   This subchapter is made by the town pursuant to the authority granted it by
I.C. 28-7-5-1 et seq., 36-1-4-11, 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-5-2-9, 36-5-4-11, 36-
8-2-4, 36-8-2-8, 36-8-2-9, 36-8-2-10 and 36-8-2-11.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:01)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 113.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PAWNBROKERS. Any person lending money on the deposit or pledge of personal
property, other than choses in action, securities or printed evidence of
indebtedness. (I.C. 28-7-5-2)
   SECONDHAND DEALER. Any person who loans money on deposit or pledge, or who
purchases secondhand property of any description.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:02)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 113.03  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE; DURATION; ISSUANCE.
   (A)   License required. No person shall own, operate or engage in the
business as a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer within the town without first
obtaining a license and complying with the provisions of this subchapter and
other relevant chapters of the code.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:03)
   (B)   Separate license for each place of business. Every person engaging in
an activity required to be licensed under this subchapter shall obtain a
license for each and every separate office or place of business conducted by
such person.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:04)
   (C)   Application for license. Application for a license required by this
subchapter shall be made in writing on forms furnished by the Clerk-Treasurer.
No person shall make a known misrepresentation or false statement on an
application. The application shall be filed with the Clerk-Treasurer and shall
include:
      (1)   The applicant’s full name and address, the address of his or her
local business establishment, the exact nature of his or her business;
      (2)   The name or title of the proposed business, profession or
occupation;
      (3)   If the applicant is not the owner of the place in which the
business is to be conducted, the name and address of the owner;
      (4)   If the applicant is a partnership, corporation or other
association, the names and addresses of all partners or principal officers;
      (5)   If the applicant is acting as an agent or employee, the name and
address of the principal or employer; and
      (6)   The attachment of a receipt from the Clerk-Treasurer showing the
payment of the license fee.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:05)
   (D)   License fees. The license fee for licenses issued under this
subchapter shall be $100 for the term of one calendar year. The license fee is
payable to the Clerk-Treasurer at the time that the application for a license
is made. If the license is denied, the fee, less $25 for the cost of the
license investigation and inspection procedure, shall be returned to the
applicant.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:06)
   (E)   Duration of license; prorated fee. All licenses issued under this
subchapter, unless specified otherwise on the license, shall be issued for the
duration of the calendar year for which they were issued, and all licenses
shall expire on December 31 of such calendar year. In the event an application
for a license goes into effect at any time after January 1 of any calendar
year, the applicant shall be required to pay for the license a pro rata part
for the portion of the year remaining up to December 31 of that year; provided,
however, that, any portion of a calendar month, except as to daily or weekly
licenses as may be provided for by the town, shall be counted as one month in
the computations of time for such remaining portion of the year.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:07)
   (F)   Investigation of applicant. Upon receipt of an application for a
license, the Clerk-Treasurer shall forward it to the Town Marshal who shall
conduct an investigation concerning the truth of the facts stated in the
application, the character of the applicant and the condition of the premises
upon which the proposed licensed activity is to take place.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:08)
   (G)   Issuance of license; denial. Within 15 calendar days of his or her
receipt of the application for a license, the Clerk-Treasurer shall approve the
application for a license unless he or she finds that:
      (1)   The applicant has been convicted of a crime, if the crime is
substantially related to the qualifications, functions or duties of the
business, profession or occupation for which the license is to be issued;
      (2)   The applicant has committed any act involving dishonesty, fraud or
deceit with intent to substantially benefit himself, herself or another, or
substantially injure another;
      (3)   The applicant knowingly made a false statement of fact required to
be revealed in the application for the license, or in any amendment or report
to be made thereunder; or
      (4)   Issuance of the license would be inconsistent with public health,
safety or general welfare.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:09)
   (H)   Notice of denial.
      (1)   Upon denial of a license, the Clerk-Treasurer shall give written
notice of such action to the applicant by first class or certified mail, which
notice shall state the reasons for the denial. Any applicant whose application
is denied may, within ten days after the mailing of the above notice, request a
hearing on such action. A hearing shall be scheduled within 30 days after the
receipt of a request for hearing.
      (2)   If no request for hearing is made within the ten-day period, the
decision of the Town Council shall be final.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:10)
   (I)   Hearing. The hearing shall be held before the Town Council, which may
reverse, modify or affirm the decision of the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:11)
   (J)   Contents of license. Every license shall state by name the person to
whom it is issued, the business, profession or occupation licensed, the address
of the place where the business, profession or occupation shall be conducted,
if applicable, and the date of issuance and date of expiration of the license.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:12)
   (K)   Revocation of license.
      (1)   A license issued under this subchapter shall be suspended or
revoked by the Town Council if the licensee is convicted of larceny or
receiving stolen goods, or if the license issued to such licensee under the
state’s Pawnbroking Law (I.C. 28-7-5-1 et seq.) has been revoked.
      (2)   A license shall be revoked or suspended if there is a finding that
the person complained of has:
         (a)   Willfully violated a term or condition of his or her license;
         (b)   Willfully done or permitted to be done an act in violation of a
statute or town ordinance relating to the business, profession or occupation
licensed; or
         (c)   Conducted the licensed business, profession or occupation in
such a manner as to constitute a threat to the public health, safety or general
welfare.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:19)
(Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.04  RENEWAL OF LICENSE; LATE RENEWAL FEES; HEARINGS.
   (A)   Every person desiring to continue in business after the expiration of
the license period shall file an application for renewal not less than 30 days
prior to the expiration of the license period. The Clerk-Treasurer may accept
an application for renewal after the time specified above if the application is
filed before the expiration of the former license; provided, however, that, the
license fee in such case shall be the renewal fee, plus 10% thereof. The Clerk-
Treasurer may accept an application for renewal filed not more than 60 days
after expiration of the former license; provided, however, that, the license
fee in such case shall be the renewal fee, plus 25%. The renewal fee shall be
$50, plus late fees.
   (B)   Except as otherwise provided by this section, the Clerk-Treasurer
shall not accept an application for a renewal of a license which has expired or
which for any other reason is not in full force and effect. If a licensee fails
to renew his or her license within the time limits set by this section, he or
she may apply for a new license; in which case, he or she shall pay the license
fee required of first-year licensees.
   (C)   If, on any renewal application, the Clerk-Treasurer has received
notice of a change of ownership or a significant change in operation of the
business, he or she may set the matter for public hearing. If such matter is
set for hearing, the applicant shall be notified by certified mail of the time
and date of the hearing, which notification shall be mailed at least ten days
prior to the hearing date. In all other cases involving license renewals, such
license shall automatically be renewed by the Clerk-Treasurer effective upon
expiration of the old license, unless a department or officer of the town
recommends denial of, or the imposition of conditions, upon such license, in
which case the matter shall be set for public hearing as provided in this
section.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:13)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 113.05  LICENSE TRANSFER PROHIBITED.
   No license issued under this subchapter shall be transferred or assigned to
another person or be used for a purpose other than that for which it was
issued.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:14)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.06  DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   Every person who is issued a license under the provisions of this subchapter
shall display the license in a conspicuous place on the premises in which the
licensed activity is being conducted; or, if there are no premises, shall carry
the license while engaged in the activity for which he or she has been
licensed, and moreover shall exhibit the same to any official of the town upon
request.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:15)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.07  REMOVAL OF PLACE OF BUSINESS; FEE.
   The license issued under this subchapter shall be valid only for the
location indicated on the license certificate. Whenever the licensee shall
change his or her place of business to another location within the town, he or
she shall apply to the Clerk-Treasurer for issuance of a new license
certificate indicating the changed location of the place of business and shall
surrender his or her old certificate. The fee for issuance of a new license
certificate shall be $10.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:16)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 113.08  RECORDS REQUIRED.
   (A)   Every pawnbroker and secondhand dealer shall keep a book, in which
shall be recorded at the time each loan, an accurate account and description,
in the English language, of the goods or article pawned, pledged or purchased,
the amount of money loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same and the name
and residence of the person pawning, pledging or selling the goods or article.
   (B)   If the goods or article is sold by weight, a true and accurate account
of the weight thereof shall also be recorded.
   (C)   No entry in such book shall be erased, obliterated or defaced.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:17)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.09  INSPECTION.
   The records prescribed in §
113.08 of this chapter, as well as the goods or article pledged, pawned or
sold, shall, at all reasonable times, be open to inspection by the Marshal or a
member of the Police Department designated by him or her.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:18)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.10  AUTHORITY OF TOWN COUNCIL.
   All persons, firms or corporations licensed under this subchapter shall be
subject to the regulation of the Town Council.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:20)  (Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983)
JUNK DEALERS, AUTOMOBILE GRAVEYARDS
§ 113.25  AUTHORITY.
   This subchapter is made by the town pursuant to the authority granted it by
I.C. 36-1-2-15, 36-1-4-11, 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-8-2-4, 36-8-2-8 and 36-8-2-
10.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:01)  (Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 113.26  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUTOMOBILE GRAVEYARD. Any establishment or place of business which is
maintained, used, or operated for storing, keeping, buying or selling wrecked,
scrapped, ruined or dismantled motor vehicles or motor vehicle parts.
   JUNK. Old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash,
rubber debris, waste or junked, dismantled or wrecked automobile, or parts
thereof, iron, steel and other old or scrap ferrous or non-ferrous material.
   JUNKYARD. An establishment or place of business which is maintained,
operated, or used for storing, keeping, buying or selling junk, or for the
maintenance or operation of an automobile graveyard, and the term shall include
garbage dumps and sanitary fills, but shall not include a scrap metal
processing facility.
   PERSON. Any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, group or
association.
   SCRAP METAL PROCESSING FACILITY. An establishment having facilities for
processing iron, steel or non-ferrous metal and whose principal product is
scrap iron, steel or scrap for sale for remelting purposes only.
   VISIBLE. Capable of being seen by a person of normal visual activity
(acuity) using the streets or alleys or from private and/or public property.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:02)  (Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 113.27  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE; SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.
   (A)   License required.
      (1)   No person shall conduct, maintain, operate, carry on or engage in
the business of junk dealer, junkyard and/or automobile graveyard without
having obtained a license thereof from the town.
      (2)   A state license is also required per I.C. 9-22.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:03)
   (B)   Application for license, requirements, fee. Any person desiring to
obtain a license to operate as a junk dealer, a junk yard and/or a automobile
graveyard shall applying writing to the Clerk-Treasurer listing his or her full
name and address and that of each officer, partner or business associate, and
the address where such person intends to carry on such business.
      (1)   The application shall also contain the following information:
         (a)   Proof that the applicant is at least 18 years of age;
         (b)   Applicant’s height, weight, color of eyes and hair;
         (c)   Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the
three years immediately preceding the date of the application;
         (d)   All criminal convictions, except minor traffic violations;
         (e)   Is the location of the junkyard and/or automobile graveyard in
compliance with the zoning ordinance;
         (f)   Is the site adequately screened or fenced so that it is not
visible from the streets or alleys or from other public property and from
private property;
         (g)   Is the site reasonably situated and screened in such a manner so
that its attraction to young children will be minimized;
         (h)   Identify the steps applicant plans to undertake to prevent the
site from being a breeding place for vermin, insects or rodents; and
         (i)   The number and location of entrances and exists to and from the
premises.
      (2)   Upon receipt of an application for a license, the Clerk-Treasurer
shall forward it to the Town Marshal who shall conduct an investigation
concerning the truth of the facts stated in the application, the character of
the applicant and the condition of the premises upon which the proposed
licensed activity is to take place.
      (3)   Upon receiving the written results of the Marshal’s investigation,
the Clerk-Treasurer shall forward the same along with the application to the
Town Council and its President for review. If it appears that the location of
the junkyard and/or automobile graveyard is in compliance with the zoning
ordinance, has adequate screening and/or fencing, and if all other is in the
best interest of the citizens of the town, then the Board of Trustees and its
president may authorize the Clerk-Treasurer to issue a license hereunder to the
applicant upon payment of the $25 annual license fee.
      (4)   (a)   The license fee shall be $25 for each calendar year or part
thereof.
         (b)   A separate license must be acquired for each site operated by
the applicant.
         (c)   All licenses issued hereunder shall expire as of December 31.
The applicant may renew his or her license upon the payment of $25 to the
Clerk-Treasurer who shall renew the license upon the application’s affirming
that the information contained in the original application is still valid.
         (d)   Any changes in the applicant’s status or in the information
contained in the original application must be reported immediately to the
Clerk-Treasurer who shall promptly transmit the same to the Town Council and
its President.
      (5)   No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a junkyard or
automobile graveyard without a current, valid license.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:04)
   (C)   Suspension or revocation of license. Licenses issued under this
subchapter may be suspended or revoked by the president of the Town Council
pursuant to the notice and hearing procedure set forth at I.C. 36-4-5-5. A
license shall be revoked or suspended of there is a finding that the person
complained of has:
      (1)   Willfully violated a term or condition of his or her license;
      (2)   Willfully done or permitted to be done an act in violation of a
statute ordinance or code of ordinances, relating to the business, profession
or occupation licensed; or
      (3)   Conducted the licensed business, profession or occupation in such a
manner as to constitute a threat to the public health, safety or general
welfare.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:07)
(Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.28  STOLEN PROPERTY.
   Every applicant who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles
or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall, upon demand,
produce such article or property to any member of the town’s Police Department
for examination.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:05)  (Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.29  RECORDS REQUIRED.
   Every person licensed under this subchapter shall keep a book in which shall
be legibly written in ink, at the time of the purchase, taking or receiving of
any goods, an accurate account and description in the English language of the
goods, articles or things purchased, taken or received; the amount of money
paid; the time of purchasing, taking or receiving the same; and the name,
residence, age, race, height and approximate weight of the person or persons
selling or delivering the goods, articles or things.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:06)  (Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.30  APPLICATION TO PRESENT BUSINESSES.
   Any person, firm, corporation or other entity currently in the business of
maintaining junk yards, junk dealers and vehicle graveyards in the town on the
date of the passage of this subchapter shall, within 60 days from the date of
passage, comply with each and every term, provision and condition, including
the licensing provision, contained herein, and the Clerk-Treasurer shall send a
copy of this subchapter along with an application for a license, by first class
mail, to those persons, firms, corporations or other entities which are
currently engaged in the business activity or operation covered by this
subchapter. Any person, firm or corporation currently engaged in the businesses
described herein, and who do not comply with each and every term of this
subchapter within 60 days from the date of its passage shall be subject to the
penalties set forth in §
113.99 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:09)  (Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   (1)   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of
§§
113.01 through
113.10 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine
of $25 and a maximum fine of $1,000, in addition to costs. A separate violation
shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs
or continues.
      (2)   In addition to the foregoing, the town is empowered to obtain a
restraining order and/or a permanent injunction against any person, firm,
corporation or any other entity who shall be in violation of §§
113.01 through
113.10 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:5:21)
   (C)   (1)   Whoever shall violate or fail to comply with any of the
provisions of §§
113.25 through
113.30 of this chapter, or shall violate or fail to comply with any order or
regulation made hereunder, shall be fined not less than $5, nor more than
$2,500. The payment of a penalty shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue, nor shall such payment be held to prevent the enforced correction of
the prohibited conditions by legal and injunctive remedies. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which such violation
occurs or continues.
      (2)   In addition to the penalty provided in division (C)(1) above, any
person, including the owner or occupant of real estate, who maintain, operate,
permit or conduct a junkyard or a vehicle graveyard without a valid license, as
required by §
113.27(A) of this chapter, shall be guilty of keeping and maintaining a
nuisance, in violation of §§
92.01 through
92.12 of this code of ordinances, and if found guilty of keeping and
maintaining a nuisance under §§
92.01 through
92.12 of this code of ordinances, the person or party shall be subject to all
of the penalties contained in §
92.99 of this code of ordinances, in addition to any penalty which may be
imposed by §§
113.25 through
113.30 of this chapter for a violation of its terms and conditions.
(Prior Code, § 6:10:08)
(Ord. 82-34, passed 2-2-1983; Ord. 82-40, passed 2-2-1983)

CHAPTER 115:  HANDBILLS
Section
   
115.01   Authority

   Related provisions, see I.C. 36-4-5-5, 36-8-2-4 and 36-8-2-10
§ 115.01  AUTHORITY.
   This chapter is made by the Town Council pursuant to the authority granted
by I.C. 36-8-2-4, 36-8-2-10 and 36-8-2-11.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:01)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COMMERCIAL HANDBILL. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed matter
which:
      (1)   Advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing;
      (2)   Directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial
establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or
indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or
      (3)   While containing reading matter other than advertising matter is
predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or
circulated for advertising purposes or for the private benefit and gain of any
person so engaged as advertiser or distributor.
   NON-COMMERCIAL HANDBILL. Any printed or written matter, any sample or
device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other
printed matter not included in the definition of a commercial handbill, as set
out in this section.
   PRIVATE PREMISES. Any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed
or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether
inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and includes
any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging
or appurtenant to such dwelling house, building or other structure.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other
public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and
buildings.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:02)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.03  DISTRIBUTION; LICENSE OR A CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   Except as provided in §
115.04 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the
business of distributing handbills or to distribute handbills without first
obtaining a license or a certificate of registration (if applicable) to do so
as hereinafter provided.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:03)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.04  EXEMPTION.
   This chapter shall have the following exceptions.
   (A)   This chapter shall not apply to persons engaged in the delivery of
daily newspapers, or any person operating a regular route, or insurance route
to solicit additional customers on a route when solicitation is incidental to
his or her regular duties, or to the producers of farm products within the
pursuit of the sale of the products raised by them.
   (B)   Additionally, this chapter shall not apply to any person authorized to
peddle or solicit without a license in the state by virtue of a state statute
providing for an exemption. The person shall be granted a certificate of
registration upon satisfactory proof being made to the Town Council that the
applicant is so exempt.
   (C)   Additionally, this chapter shall not apply to any person engaged in
the exercise of his or her right of free speech as it pertains to religion and/
or political conviction as long as the person or persons are only speaking or
promoting their cause without the solicitation of funds or sale of materials or
products.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:04)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.05  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE.
   (A)   Any person desiring to obtain a license to distribute handbills or to
engage in the business of distributing handbills shall apply in person to the
Clerk-Treasurer and complete an application in writing listing his or her full
name and address and that of each officer, partner or business associate.
   (B)   The applicant shall also list the full names and addresses of all
persons by and on behalf of whom the handbills are to be distributed, if
satisfied that the information furnished by the applicant is true and that no
fraud or misrepresentation will be perpetrated upon the residents of the town,
the Clerk-Treasurer shall, within 15 days from the date of the receipt of the
application, issue the license upon payment of the fees prescribed in §
115.06 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:05)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.06  LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee for distribution of handbills or engaging in the business of
distributing handbills shall be $2 for a period of one day and $5 for a period
of seven consecutive days.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:06)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.07  DISCARDING OR THROWING IN PUBLIC PLACES.
   No person shall discard or throw any commercial or non-commercial handbill
in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the town.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:07)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.08  DEPOSITING ON UNINHABITED OR VACANT PRIVATE PREMISES.
   No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or non-
commercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or
continuously uninhabited or vacant.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:08)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.09  DISTRIBUTING PROHIBITED WHERE SIGNS POSTED.
   No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or non-
commercial handbill upon any private premises, if requested by anyone thereon
not to do so, or if there is placed on said premises in a conspicuous position
near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words, “no trespassing”, “no
peddlers or agents”, “no advertisement” or any similar notice, indicating in
any manner that the occupants of said premises do not desire to be molested or
have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such handbills left upon
such premises.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:09)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.10  DISTRIBUTING AT INHABITED PRIVATE PREMISES.
   No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or non-
commercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by
handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or
other person then present in or upon such private premises; provided, however,
that, in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted, as provided
in this chapter, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not
to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited
private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or
prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or
sidewalks, streets or other public places; and, except that, mailboxes may not
be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. The
provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the
United States, nor to newspapers; except that, newspapers shall be placed on
private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or
deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or
upon private property.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:10)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)  Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.11  REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   A license or certificate of registration issued under this chapter may be
revoked by the President of the Town Council for violation of any provision of
this chapter or any law of the state, or ordinance or code of ordinances of the
town, for giving any false information on the application for a certificate of
registration or a license, or for any other conduct which threatens the peace
and security of the citizens of the town. Revocation under this section shall
be in accordance with the notice and hearing procedures se forth in I.C. 36-4-
5-5.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:11)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.12  DENIAL OF LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION; NOTICE; HEARING.
   (A)   Upon denial of a license under §
115.05 of this chapter, the Clerk-Treasurer shall give written notice of such
action to the applicant by first class or certified mail, which notice shall
state the reasons for the denial. Any applicant whose application is denied
may, within ten days after the mailing of the above, request a hearing on such
action before the Town Council. A hearing shall be scheduled within 30 days
after the receipt of a request for a hearing.
   (B)   If no request for a hearing is made within the ten-day period, the
decision of the Clerk-Treasurer shall be final.
   (C)   The hearing shall be held before the Town Council which may reverse,
modify or affirm the action of the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:12)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.13  INFORMATION.
   Upon request, any person distributing handbills shall provide the following
information and evidence of identification to the Marshal or to any officer,
employer or agent of the town: drivers license; name and address; date of
birth; Social Security number; name and address of person, firm or corporation
which is causing and/or paying for the distribution of the handbills; and any
other information requested.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:13)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.14  AUTHORITY OF TOWN COUNCIL.
   All persons, firms or corporations receiving a certificate of registration
under §§
111.01 through
111.10 of this code of ordinances or licensed under this chapter shall be
subject to the regulation of the Town Council.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:15)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
§ 115.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this
chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine of $25 and a
maximum fine of $300, in addition to costs. A separate violation shall be
deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   (B)   In addition to the foregoing, the town is empowered to obtain a
restraining order and/or a permanent injunction against any person, firm,
corporation or any other entity who shall be in violation of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:7:14)  (Ord. 82-31, passed 2-2-1983)
CHAPTER 116:  GARBAGE PICKUP AND DISPOSAL
Section
   
116.01   Authority
   
116.02   License required
   
116.03   Hours of operation
   
116.04   Disposal
   
116.05   Authority of Town Council
   
116.06   License revocation
   
116.07   Application to present collectors, haulers
 
   
116.99   Penalty
§ 116.01  AUTHORITY.
   This chapter is made by the town pursuant to the authority granted it by
I.C. 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-5-2-9, 36-5-4-11, 36-8-2-4 and 36-8-2-10.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:01)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)
§ 116.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   (1)   No person shall engage in the business of hauling trash,
garbage, rubbish, refuse, ashes or debris over or along any of the streets or
alleys of the town without first having applied for and obtained a license to
do so from the Clerk-Treasurer’s office.
      (2)   The fee for such license shall be $25 payable at the time of the
filing of the application.
      (3)   The license shall be for a one-year period commencing on the date
that the license is issued.
   (B)   In applying for a license, the applicant shall indicate the following:
      (1)   The frequency of said pickup;
      (2)   The number of people working on the truck;
      (3)   The location and address of the disposal of the trash, garbage,
rubbish and refuse;
      (4)   The type and size of vehicle used in the operation;
      (5)   Name, address, telephone number, Social Security number and age of
the applicant; and
      (6)   Types and amounts of insurance coverage for damage to property and
for death and/or injuries to persons.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:02)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)  Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.03  HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (A)   Every person, firm, corporation, partnership or sole proprietorship
engaged in the business of hauling, carrying and/or collecting trash, debris,
garbage or rubbish over or along any of the streets or alleys of the town shall
conduct said business within the town’s corporate boundaries between the hours
of 7:00 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. of the same day.
   (B)   Said business shall not be conducted after 5:30 p.m. or before 7:00
a.m.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:03)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)  Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.04  DISPOSAL.
   (A)   No person, firm, corporation, partnership or sole proprietorship
engaged in the business of hauling, carrying and/or collecting trash, debris,
garbage, refuse or rubbish over or along any of the streets or alleys of the
town shall either temporarily or permanently, dispose of the same within the
municipal boundaries of the town, except in a licensed landfill and/or dump,
and a collector shall not cause said trash, debris, garbage, refuse or rubbish
to be burned within the corporate boundaries of the town.
   (B)   A collector shall not permit trash, debris, garbage, refuse or rubbish
to remain on or stored in a parked vehicle for a period in excess of 18 hours.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:04)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)  Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.05  AUTHORITY OF TOWN COUNCIL.
   All persons, firms or corporations licensed under this chapter shall be
subject to the regulation of the Town Council.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:05)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)
§ 116.06  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Pursuant to the notice and procedure requirements of I.C. 36-4-5-5, the
President of the Town Council may revoke or suspend the license issued
hereunder to any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this
chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:06)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)
§ 116.07  APPLICATION TO PRESENT COLLECTORS, HAULERS.
   Any person, firm, corporation or other entity currently in the business of
collecting, picking-up, disposing and/or hauling trash, garbage, rubbish,
refuse and/or ashes over and along any of the streets or alleys of the town on
the date of the passage of this chapter shall, within 60 days from the date of
passage, comply with each and every term, provision and condition, including
the licensing provision, contained herein, and the Clerk-Treasurer shall send a
copy of this chapter along with an application for a license, by first class
mail, to those persons, firms, corporations or other entities which are
currently engaged in the business activity or operation covered by this
chapter. Any person, firm or corporation currently in the business of picking
up and/or disposing of trash, garbage, rubbish, refuse and ashes and ashes and
who do not comply with each and every term of this chapter within 60 days from
the date of its passage shall be subject to the penalties set forth in §
116.99 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:08)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)  Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this
chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine of $25 and a
maximum fine of $300 in addition to costs. A separate violation shall be deemed
committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   In addition to the foregoing, the town is empowered to obtain a
restraining order and/or a permanent injunction against any person, firm,
corporation or any other entity who shall be in violation of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 6:9:07)  (Ord. 82-25, passed 1-19-1983)
TITLE XIII:  GENERAL OFFENSES
   Chapter
      
130.   GENERAL OFFENSES
CHAPTER 130:  GENERAL OFFENSES
Section
   
130.01   Synthetic cannabinoids
   
130.02   Property; damaging, destroying or defacing
   
130.03   Firearms and dangerous knives
   
130.04   [Reserved]

130.99   Penalty
§ 130.01  SYNTHETIC CANNABINOIDS.
   (A)   Products containing synthetic cannabinoids (“products”) such as K2/
Spice, or similar products which contain an analogue or a derivative of any of
the chemical compounds specified in the state statutes, shall not be sold,
marketed or offered for sale the town; and products containing synthetic
cannabinoids (“products”) may not be burned, incinerated or ignited in any
public place or on any property owned, leased or controlled by the town.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, an ANALOGUE or a DERIVATIVE is defined
as a new or novel chemical entity, independent of synthetic route or natural
origin, having substantially the same carbon backbone structure as any of the
substances defined in the state statutes and having substantially the same
pharmacological mechanism of action.
(Ord. 2012-03, passed 1-26-2012)  Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.02  PROPERTY; DAMAGING, DESTROYING OR DEFACING.
   (A)   Intentional acts causing damage to property of the town. No person
shall maliciously, willfully or intentionally break, damage, destroy, remove,
take, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, equipment,
vehicles, traffic-control devices including traffic signs or with any other
property, either real or personal property, which belongs to, or is a part of,
or which is in the possession of the town.
(Prior Code, § 7:1:01)
   (B)   Negligent or unintentional acts causing damage to property of the
town. Any person, firm or corporation whose negligent or unintentional conduct,
omission or act causes a structure, appurtenance, equipment, vehicle, traffic-
control device including traffic signs, or any other property, either real or
personal property, belonging to or is a part of, or which is in the possession
of the town to be broken, damaged, destroyed, removed, taken, uncovered,
defaced or tampered with shall be liable to the town for all expenses, losses
or damages, including attorney fees and costs, sustained or caused the town in
connection with the said negligent or unintentional conduct, act or omission.
(Prior Code, § 7:1:03)
(Ord. 82-46, passed 5-4-1983)  Penalty, see §
130.99
Statutory reference:
   Authority, see I.C. 36-1-4-3, 36-1-4-6 and 36-5-2-9
§ 130.03  FIREARMS AND DANGEROUS KNIVES.
   (A)   Authority. This section is made by the town pursuant to the authority
granted it by I.C. 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-5-2-2-9, 36-5-4-11, 36-8-2-4 and 36-
8-2-10.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:01)
   (B)   Firearms.
      (1)   Definition of “firearm”. The term FIREARM means any weapon which is
capable of or designed to or which may readily be converted to expel a
projectile with deadly force by means of an explosion.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:02)
      (2)   Shooting of firearms prohibited. No person shall fire or discharge,
or cause to be fired or discharged, within the boundaries of the town any
firearm.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:03)
      (3)   Exceptions. This section, as it pertains to firearms, shall not
apply to peace officers or soldiers in the discharge of their official duties
and while in the exercise of reasonable care; nor to a person using firearms in
necessary self-defense.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:04)
   (C)   Dangerous knives.
      (1)   Definition of “dangerous knife”.DANGEROUS KNIFE means any knife
having a blade more than three and one-half inches in length, any dagger,
sword, bayonet, bolo knife, hatchet, straight-edge razor or razor blade not in
a package, dispenser or shaving appliance.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:05)
      (2)   Possession and sale of dangerous knives. It is unlawful for anyone
to knowingly carry concealed on his or her person or in any vehicle any
dangerous knife, or to sell or give away to any person under 18 years of age a
dangerous knife, or for any person under 18 years of age to purchase or possess
a dangerous knife.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:06)
      (3)   Exemptions. Division (C)(2) above shall not apply to:
         (a)   Individual licensed hunters or fishermen while on hunting,
camping or fishing trips;
         (b)   Any person over 18 years of age carrying such knife in a secure
wrapper from or to the place of purchase, to or from a place of repair or to
his or her home or place of business;
         (c)   Any person while in his or her place of abode or fixed place of
business.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:07)
(Ord. 82-26, passed 1-19-1983)  Penalty, see §
130.99
Statutory reference:
   Related provisions, see I.C. 36-1-6-2, 36-1-6-4, 36-5-2-9, 36-5-4-11, 36-8-
2-4 and 36-8-2-10
§ 130.04  [RESERVED].
§ 130.05  [RESERVED].
§ 130.06  FIREWORKS.
   (A)   Definition of “consumer fireworks”. For purposes of this section,
CONSUMER FIREWORKS shall mean consumer fireworks as defined by I.C. 22-11-14-1.
(Prior Code, § 7:5:01)
   (B)   Days and hours of use. Consumer fireworks may not be used, ignited or
discharged within the corporate limits of the town, except during the following
times:
      (1)   Between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and two hours after sunset on June
29, June 30, July 1, July 2, July 3, July 5, July 6, July 7, July 8 and July 9;
      (2)   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 a.m. on July 4; and
      (3)   Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31 and 1:00 a.m. on
January 1.
(Prior Code, § 7:5:02)
   (C)   Nuisance. Use or discharge of fireworks which causes serious annoyance
or disturbance to a neighborhood or the residents therein by loud, frequent or
habitual noise is declared to be a nuisance, it is unlawful for any person to
conduct such activities, and the town may seek injunctive relief in a court of
law to prevent such activities in addition to seeking a monetary penalty as set
forth hereinbelow.
(Prior Code, § 7:5:03)
   (D)   Control of a minor. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or
other adult person having the care, custody and control of a minor under the
age of 18 years to knowingly permit such minor to fire, shoot off or discharge
any fireworks within the limits of the town.
(Prior Code, § 7:5:04)
   (E)   Liability for cost of fire services. Any person shall be liable for
damage to person or property caused by the use or discharge of fireworks, and
shall also be liable for costs of fire service by a responding fire department,
as defined in I.C. 22-11-14-1, or other emergency services necessitated by the
use or discharge of fireworks.
(Prior Code, § 7:5:05)
(Ord. 2007-3, passed 8-20-2007)  Penalty, see §
130.99
Cross-reference:
   Fireworks Displays, see §§
112.20 through
112.22
Statutory reference:
   Related provisions, see I.C. 22-11-14-1
§ 130.99  PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   Whoever violates §
130.01 of this chapter shall be fined as follows:
      (1)   First violation: $250, plus costs, which shall be paid and
processed through the town’s Ordinance Violation Bureau;
      (2)   Second violation: in the event a second violation occurs within 90
consecutive days of the issuance of the first violation, the fine shall be
$750, plus costs, which shall be paid through the County Prosecutor’s office
and/or county courts in accordance with I.C. 33-36-2-3; and
      (3)   Additional violations: in the event there are any additional
violation(s) within one year from the date of the issuance of the second
violation, then the violator will be subject to a fine of $2,500, plus costs,
with each day thereafter constituting a separate offense shall subject the
violator to a separate fine of $2,500, plus costs, per day. Payment shall be
paid through the County Prosecutor’s office and/or county courts in accordance
with I.C. 33-36-2-3. If, after multiple violations by the same person or
entity, the Town Attorney and/or the County Prosecutor’s office, and the town’s
Police Department have reasons to believe that the imposition of fines will not
be effective in enforcing this chapter, the Town Attorney and/or the County
Prosecutor’s office shall be empowered to seek any other remedies provided by
law.
   (C)   (1)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of §
130.02(A) of this chapter, or who undertakes, permits or allows an act or
conduct prohibited herein, shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum
fine of $25 and a maximum fine of $2,500, in addition to costs.
      (2)   In addition to the fine imposed by division (C)(1) above, a person,
firm or corporation violating any provision of §
130.02(A) of this chapter shall be liable to the town for all expenses, losses
or damages, including attorney fees and costs, sustained or caused by town in
connection with the violation.
(Prior Code, § 7:1:02)
   (D)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of §
130.03 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine
of $25 and a maximum fine of $2,500, in addition to costs. Each incident shall
constitute a separate violation under §
130.03 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 7:2:08)
   (E)   Any child, parent, guardian or custodian who violates any provision of
§
130.04 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine
of $25 and the maximum fine of $250, in addition to costs. Each incident shall
constitute a separate violation hereunder.
(Prior Code, § 7:3:01)
   (F)   Any person who violates any provision of §
130.05 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished with a minimum fine
of $10 and a maximum fine of $200, in addition to costs. Each incident shall
constitute a separate violation under §
130.05 of this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 7:4:03)
   (G)   Any person violating any of the provisions of §
130.06 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine in an amount of $50 for the
first violation, payable at the Town Hall. Any subsequent violation shall
subject the violator to a fine of up to $2,500 per violation. In addition to
any fine and court costs, violators shall reimburse the town for the cost of
responding emergency services, if any.
(Prior Code, § 7:5:06)
(Ord. 82-26, passed 1-19-1983; Ord. 82-36, passed 2-2-1983; Ord. 82-46, passed
5-4-1983; Ord. 82-49, passed 9-7-1983; Ord. 2000-3, passed 10-2-2000; Ord.
2007-3, passed 8-20-2007; Ord. 2012-03, passed 1-26-2012)
